 The only thing I ever heard was that mini black holes could be created... a lot of news outlets blow scientific stuff out of proportion. The general consensus was that the black holes would be microscopic (if they occurred) and would evaporate from Hawking radiation and not cause any harm (of course there was no real way for them to know for sure).
 
 A lot of the things that are seen as 'science lying' are often the media trying to make a story before a paper is published and reviewed, before all the evidence is in, or simply trying to push an agenda and get ratings. Even with global warming (which is a real issue), guys like Al Gore have done more harm than good by getting some of the facts wrong and making the whole thing lose credibility with the public.

 Not that I didn't believe you, but I looked the glacier thing up anyway (I thought the story sounded familiar) and found it.
 
 World misled over Himalayan glacier meltdown - Times Online
 
 It was indeed a mistake (I'm not claiming there aren't mistakes in science), but again science corrected itself and admitted its mistake. 
 
 This was actually pretty interesting in that a popular science magazine (not peer reviewed) seemed to publish the info about the glaciers melting by 2035 based on a scientist's speculation. 
 
 

 It has also emerged that the New Scientist report was itself based on a short telephone interview with Syed Hasnain, a little-known Indian scientist then based at Jawaharlal Nehru University in Delhi.
 
 Hasnain has since admitted that the claim was "speculation" and was not supported by any formal research.
 
 ....
 
 "Hasnain told me then that he was bringing a report containing those numbers to Britain. The report had not been peer reviewed or formally published in a scientific journal and it had no formal status so I reported his work on that basis. 

 
 If that was the end of it I could have just said "See, the media strikes again!" but then apparently the WWF cited that info in a campaigning report, which later was cited by the IPCC who erroneously put it in a report without fact/source checking. 
 
 Anyway, your original quote was...
 
 
There are plenty of liars and crazies in the scientific world( quite a few making a living exagerating the dangers of 'global warming').

 
 and I was just pointing out that it was an exaggeration, that the misleading is almost always done by media or politicians, and that the idea of scientific conspiracies where scientists are purposely misleading the public is not really happening (and as I pointed out in my last post, it's virtually impossible long-term with the peer review process). 
 
 This isn't to say that individual scientists would never lie or fudge results or whatever, but your comment just came off as kind of conspiracy theory-ish.
